hanzi-su-wiki:
紀

Значения

Хроника, летопись; регистрация; порядок, правило; эпоха, период

Мнемоника

Считается, до введения иероглифики в Китае было узелковое письмо. Для себя 己 можно не делать запись, а просто завязать на нитке 糸 узелок.

Варианты

纪

koohiiStory1: In a CHRONICLE the THREAD of the story can twist and turn like a SNAKE.
koohiiStory2: Worst fan fiction ever....SPIDERMAN joins the CHRONICLES of narnia to battle a big SNAKE!!
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The thread you weave together to tell others about oneself is the account of your life. It's your very own narrative, tying everything you've been through together.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Picture this account of your life, the thread of the narrative linking all of the different important points in your life together.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: You take this account and lock it with a special key (き). You only give this key to people you really trust, so they can read the account of your life and truly understand you.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Picture the people in your life that you'd give this special key to. They'd get to read the account of your life, so make sure they're trustworthy before you hand that key over.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Spiderman's superhero epoch comes to an end when he meets his toughest enemy yet, the snake villain.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The seal script starts with "糸" and "自". The original meaning is a rope that binds and binds the threads. "Shu Wen": "Ji, Si Fare also. From Shito, Ji Sheng." There is only " ji " in ancient Chinese characters but no " ji ". The so-called "silk other" refers to the silk thread, although extremely tortuous, but the whole story of its own, and each may have other meaning, from which " has also clearly visible" word coiled shape. " Had " because the word has been borrowed for the "heavenly" and the already "own", because not long false return, later was filling a " Ito " from " Ji " word, refer to " own ."

Bronze words use " ji " to mean " ji ", as the names of princes, such as Jihou Zhong: "ji (ji)hou".

Ancient pottery and seal characters are used as surnames, see "Ancient Pottery Collection" 3.741 and "Ancient Seal Collection" 2611.

Simplified and silk scripts are used as "discipline, general and regular", such as "Mawangdui Han silk script. The 68th line of Ten Questions: "Every rule of righteousness (government) must begin by itself"; another example is "Mawangdui Han Silk Book." The 122nd line of Lao Zi's Old Unknown Book before the Second Volume: "Chaos"; another example is "Mawangdui Han Silk Book." The 147th line of the Old Unknown Book before the First Volume of Lao Zi: "The Chronicle of Heaven and Earth".

The ancient book " Ji " is used as a general term for the seasons of celestial phenomena, such as "Shang Shu‧ Hong Fan": "Fifth Period: One is the year, the second is the month, the third is the day, the fourth is the stars, and the fifth is the calendar number"; "Tang Ji", such as "Mao Shi‧ Daya‧Wen Wang Zhi Shi·Fu Pu": "Encourage my king, Gang Ji Si Fang", or such as "Mo Zi‧ Shang Tong": "For example, if the silk thread has the discipline, the ignorant has Gang"; another example of Ban Gu's "You Tong Fu": "Emperor Ten Ji and Hong Jian Xi".

The ancient book " Ji " is also known as " ji ", which means records, such as "Zuo Zhuan. "The Second Year of Huan Gong": "Cultural and relics are recorded in records", which means to record with patterns and colors.
humanum_short_description_en: Seal script starts with the sound of "糸" and "自". The original meaning is a rope that binds and binds the threads.
humanum_full_description:
篆文從「糸」，「己」聲，本義為編結繫聯約束絲縷的繩子。《說文》：「紀，絲別也。从糸，己聲。」古文字中只有「己」而無「紀」。所謂「絲別」，是指絲縷雖極盤曲，但自有始末，而可各自有別的意思，這從「己」字盤曲的字形亦清晰可見。「己」字因被借作「天干」的己和「自己」的己，因久假不歸，後世才加注一「糸」而成「紀」字，參見「己」。

　　金文用「己」表示「紀」，作諸侯名，如紀侯鐘：「己（紀）侯」。

　　古陶、印璽文字用作姓氏，見於《古陶文彙編》3.741和《古璽彙編》2611。

　　簡帛文字用作「紀律、綱常」，如《馬王堆漢帛書．十問》第68行：「凡治正（政）之紀，必自身始」；又如《馬王堆漢帛書．老子乙本卷前古佚書》第122行：「亂紀」；再如《馬王堆漢帛書．老子乙本卷前古佚書》第147行：「天地之紀」。

　　古書「紀」用作天象時令的總稱，如《尚書‧洪範》：「五紀：一曰歲，二曰月，三曰日，四曰星辰，五曰厤數」；亦用作「綱紀」，如《毛詩‧大雅‧文王之什‧棫樸》：「勉勉我王，綱紀四方」，或如《墨子‧尚同上》：「譬若絲縷之有紀，罔罟之有綱」；又如班固〈幽通賦〉：「皇十紀而鴻漸兮」。

　　古書「紀」又通為「記」，表示記載，如《左傳．桓公二年》：「文、物以紀之」，意謂用紋飾、色彩來記錄。
humanum_short_description: 篆文從「糸」，「己」聲，本義為編結繫聯約束絲縷的繩子。

紀紀RS
纪纪 		record, annal, historical account, chronicles
  • the weaving 己 strings 糸 of history put down in weaving 己 lines 糸 of writing
(Simplified: 纪)
Chinese Definition:
Pictophonetic: 己 indicates the sound; 糹 (thread) conveys the meaning.
  • ⿰ Left to right
    • 糹 [ sī ] silk; thread
    • 己 [ jǐ ] self, oneself; personal, private; 6th heavenly stem
①記載：紀年。紀元。紀行(xíng)。紀實。紀念。紀傳(zhuàn)體(中國傳統史書的一種體裁，以人物傳記爲中心敘述史實，“紀”是帝王本紀，“傳”是其他人物的列傳)。紀事本末體(中國傳統史書的一種體裁，以重要事件爲綱，將一段歷史完整地記載下來)。
②記年代的方式：一紀(古代指十二年)。世紀(一百年)。
③地質年代分期的第二級，紀以下爲“世”，紀以上爲“代”。
④法度：紀律。違法亂紀。
⑤散絲的頭緒：絲縷有紀。
紀念 [ jì niàn ]: to commemorate; to remember; Classifiers: 个
紀錄 [ jì lù ]: variant of 记录 (but in Taiwan, not for the verb sense "to record")
(Simplified: 纪)

世紀(せいき): century, era

篆文從「 糸 」，「 己 」聲，本義為編結繫聯約束絲縷的繩子。《說文》：「紀，絲別也。从糸，己聲。」古文字中只有「 己 」而無「 紀 」。所謂「絲別」，是指絲縷雖極盤曲，但自有始末，而可各自有別的意思，這從「 己 」字盤曲的字形亦清晰可見。「 己 」字因被借作「天干」的己和「自己」的己，因久假不歸，後世才加注一「 糸 」而成「 紀 」字，參見「 己 」。 金文用「 己 」表示「 紀 」，作諸侯名，如紀侯鐘：「己（紀）侯」。 古陶、印璽文字用作姓氏，見於《古陶文彙編》3.741和《古璽彙編》2611。 簡帛文字用作「紀律、綱常」，如《馬王堆漢帛書．十問》第68行：「凡治正（政）之紀，必自身始」；又如《馬王堆漢帛書．老子乙本卷前古佚書》第122行：「亂紀」；再如《馬王堆漢帛書．老子乙本卷前古佚書》第147行：「天地之紀」。 古書「 紀 」用作天象時令的總稱，如《尚書‧洪範》：「五紀：一曰歲，二曰月，三曰日，四曰星辰，五曰厤數」；亦用作「綱紀」，如《毛詩‧大雅‧文王之什‧棫樸》：「勉勉我王，綱紀四方」，或如《墨子‧尚同上》：「譬若絲縷之有紀，罔罟之有綱」；又如班固〈幽通賦〉：「皇十紀而鴻漸兮」。 古書「 紀 」又通為「 記 」，表示記載，如《左傳．桓公二年》：「文、物以紀之」，意謂用紋飾、色彩來記錄。
Elaboration: The seal script starts with " 糸" and " 自". The original meaning is a rope that binds and binds the threads. "Shu Wen": "Ji, Si Fare also. From Shito, Ji Sheng." There is only " ji" in ancient Chinese characters but no " ji". The so-called "silk other" refers to the silk thread, although extremely tortuous, but the whole story of its own, and each may have other meaning, from which " has also clearly visible" word coiled shape. " Had" because the word has been borrowed for the "heavenly" and the already "own", because not long false return, later was filling a " Ito" from " Ji" word, refer to " own." Bronze words use " ji" to mean " ji", as the names of princes, such as Jihou Zhong: "ji (ji)hou". Ancient pottery and seal characters are used as surnames, see "Ancient Pottery Collection" 3.741 and "Ancient Seal Collection" 2611. Simplified and silk scripts are used as "discipline, general and regular", such as "Mawangdui Han silk script. The 68th line of Ten Questions: "Every rule of righteousness (government) must begin by itself"; another example is "Mawangdui Han Silk Book." The 122nd line of Lao Zi's Old Unknown Book before the Second Volume: "Chaos"; another example is "Mawangdui Han Silk Book." The 147th line of the Old Unknown Book before the First Volume of Lao Zi: "The Chronicle of Heaven and Earth". The ancient book " Ji" is used as a general term for the seasons of celestial phenomena, such as "Shang Shu‧ Hong Fan": "Fifth Period: One is the year, the second is the month, the third is the day, the fourth is the stars, and the fifth is the calendar number"; "Tang Ji", such as "Mao Shi‧ Daya‧Wen Wang Zhi Shi·Fu Pu": "Encourage my king, Gang Ji Si Fang", or such as "Mo Zi‧ Shang Tong": "For example, if the silk thread has the discipline, the ignorant has Gang"; another example of Ban Gu's "You Tong Fu": "Emperor Ten Ji and Hong Jian Xi". The ancient book " Ji" is also known as " ji", which means records, such as "Zuo Zhuan. "The Second Year of Huan Gong": "Cultural and relics are recorded in records", which means to record with patterns and colors.

Radicals: 糸, 己  (thread, oneself)
Meaning Mnemonic
The thread you weave together to tell others about oneself is the account of your life. It's your very own narrative, tying everything you've been through together.
Picture this account of your life, the thread of the narrative linking all of the different important points in your life together.
Reading Mnemonic
You take this account and lock it with a special key (き). You only give this key to people you really trust, so they can read the account of your life and truly understand you.
Picture the people in your life that you'd give this special key to. They'd get to read the account of your life, so make sure they're trustworthy before you hand that key over.
